results.justification: The paper explicitly states the methodology, focusing on feature engineering and machine learning for collusion detection. "We used feature engineering and ML algorithms to create a model for the detection of collusion."

Sections 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the experimental design, including dataset creation, feature engineering, and the methods used for model training and validation.

The paper states: "To enhance the usability and reproducibility of our work, we have open-sourced the iQuiz tool and made the collected data publicly available." and provides a DOI: https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.23744283.v1
Section 3.1 and 3.2 describe the dataset, including variables (Student, Question, Response, Score, Start, Revisions, Time) and their formats. Table 3 provides a feature information table.
Section 3.1 details the data collection methods, including the use of iQuiz, Moodle integration, and the collection of clickstream data. It also describes the experimental and empirical settings.
The paper states: "we have open-sourced the iQuiz tool..." implying the code is available.
While the iQuiz tool is open-sourced, the paper does not explicitly state whether the scripts for data cleaning, analysis, and visualization are also shared in a repository.

The paper uses machine learning classifiers (LR, SVM, DT, XGB, RF) and reports performance metrics like accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score. Statistical methods like stratified five-fold cross-validation and SMOTE are also described.
The analysis is primarily quantitative. While the personality test provides some contextual information, it's used to support quantitative findings rather than being a core qualitative analysis.
The paper does not mention or link to any preregistration.
The paper presents the results of the experiments, including the performance of different classifiers and the feature importance analysis (Section 4).
Section 5 discusses limitations, including the use of experimental datasets and the potential for coincidental observations or false accusations.
